questions.text: What is the most common complication of this condition,if left untreated?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malunion, Cubitus Varus Given image favors the diagnosis of supracondylar fracture of humerus; which refers to transverse or oblique fracture of the distal humerus just above the elbow joint. Malunion leading to cubitus varus in association with AIN injury is the most common complication if this fracture is left untreated. Neuropraxia associated with supracondylar fracture of humerus: anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) neurapraxia (branch of median n.): most common nerve palsy seen with supracondylar humerus fractures Unable to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb and the distal interphalangeal joint of the index finger (can't make A-OK sign) Radial nerve palsy: second most common neuropraxia Loss of sensation over volar index finger

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B: Cubitus valgus is one of the most common complications seen with untreated radial head dislocation. OPTION C : Ulnar nerve palsy seen with flexion-type injury patterns Inability to extend wrist, MCP joints, thumb IP joint; while PIP and DIP can still be extended via intrinsic function (ulnar nerve) OPTION D : Myositis ossificans is a reactive soft tissue bone-forming process that commonly occurs following a traumatic event to soft tissues and is typically seen with a history of fracture in children or adolescents improperly treated by massage or intensive stretching.

Table:

#MANTRA IMPORTANT CONDITIONS OF THE ELBOW Little leaguer's elbow Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle Javelin thrower's elbow Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action Student's elbow/Miner's elbow Olecranon bursitis Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the type of fixation shown in the image?

options.label: A
options.text: Spanning External Fixator – Fracture Shaft Tibia

options.label: B
options.text: Spanning External Fixator – Fracture Shaft Femur

options.label: C
options.text: Spanning External Fixator – Peri Articular Fracture Knee

questions.correct_answer: C. Spanning External Fixator – Peri Articular Fracture Knee
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spanning External Fixator – Peri Articular Fracture Knee Given image shows a joint spanning/bridging external fixator. A joint-spanning external fixator is fixed to the bones forming the joint from both sides (femur and the tibia) while the fracture zone is left virtually untouched (it is bridged). It may be used on its own or to supplement K-wire fixation and is specifically preferred in periarticular fractures of knee or wrist. (Thus Option C is a better choice than A or B in this case.)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option D: The Ilizarov apparatus (circular external fixator, 3 rd generation fixation technique) is used to lengthen or reshape limb bones/long bones; treat complex and/or open bone fractures; and in cases of infected non-unions of bones that are not amenable with other techniques. It is not usually preferred for periarticular fractures. OPTION A and B is not the correct answer.

Table:

#MANTRA #instruments in orthopedics PERIOSTEAL ELEVATOR CURETTE OSTEOTOME BONE GAUGE BONE NIBBLER BONE AND PLATE HOLDING FORCEP

questions.text: A patient developed dyspnea and difficulty in breathing 2 days after admitting in the hospital because of multiple injuries due to RTA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fat Embolism The likely diagnosis is fat embolism Fat embolism syndrome Usually seen on 2nd - 3rd day after fracture of long bones Occurs in population with fat in medullary cavity (adults)

Highyeild:

Classical triad Respiratory symptoms- Dyspnoea/Tachypnoea Neurological symptoms- Confusion/Disorientation Petechial rash in Axilla, neck, periumbilical area GURD’S CRITERIA FOR DIAGNOSIS OF FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME: Major criteria (one necessary for diagnosis) Petechial rash Respiratory insufficiency Cerebral involvement Minor criteria (four necessary for diagnosis) Tachycardia > 120 beats/min Fever Retinal changes: fat or petechiae Jaundice Renal signs: anuria or oliguria Thrombocytopenia Anemia High erythrocyte sedimentation rate Fat macroglobinemia X-ray: Bilateral fluffy shadows develop as respiratory insufficiency worsens- SNOW STORM appearance CT chest: Focal areas of ground glass opacity with interlobular septal thickening Ill-defined subpleural nodules TREATMENT: Adequate O2 & ventilation Hemodynamic stability (blood hydration, prophylaxis for DVT) Heparins: lipase activity Corticosteroids Surgical: Early fixation of fracture (Delay of intervention increases chance of fat embolism)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Air embolism aka gas embolism, is an entity with the potential for severe morbidity and mortality. It is a predominantly iatrogenic complicationthat occurs when atmospheric gas is introduced into the systemic (usually venous) system. It should be suspected in a patient with similar signs and symptoms but with more acute onset of symptoms. Option C: Pulmonary hypertension may be seen with similar signs and symptoms but the classic history of right ventricular failure and associated signs and symptoms would be seen instead of history of fracture before 2 days. Option D: Thromboembolism would be seen usually in a patient on bedrest or in a patient who recently suffered MI or arrhythmia causing clots.

Table:

#MANTRA GURD’S CRITERIA Major criteria | Respiratory symptoms, signs, radiographic changes 2 Cerebral involvement 3 Petechial rash Minor criteria 1 Pyrexia (usually >38.5°C) 2 Tachycardia (>110 beats/min) 3 Retinal changes (fat or petechiae) 4 Jaundice 5 Renal changes (anuria or oliguria) 6 A drop of more than 20% of the admission haemoglobin value 7 Sudden thrombocytopenia (a drop of >50% of the admission thrombocyte value) 8 High erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR > 71 mm/h) 9Fat macroglobulinemia
